title-group.article-title: The background to the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise

author-notes.corresp: AS Kaddour, QinetiQ, Ively Rd, Farnborough, Hampshire, GU14 0LX, UK Email: askaddour@qinetiq.com

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Evaluation of Theories for Predicting Failure in Polymer Composite Laminates Under 3-D States of Stress: Part A of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II)

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In 2004, the authors completed the First World-Wide Failure Exercise dealing with benchmarking recognised failure criteria under two-dimensional, in-plane loadings. Based on the success and the lessons learnt, and using the same strategy, the authors have organised the ‘Second World-Wide Failure Exercise’. It aims at filling key gaps identified and establishing the status of 12 theoretical methods for predicting failure in fibre-reinforced composite materials subjected to three-dimensional or (triaxial) states of stress. This paper gives an account of the background to the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise, the process of completing the first part (Part A) and a summary of key conclusions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Failure criteria and robust modelling capabilities for fibre-reinforced polymer composites are essential aids in the successful and efficient design of light weight structures. The authors, since 1992, began a series of coordinated studies (known as the ‘World-Wide Failure Exercise’ or ‘WWFE’) to provide a comprehensive description of the foremost failure theories for fibre-reinforced plastic (FRP) laminates that were available at the time, a comparison of their predictive capabilities directly with each other, and a comparison of their predictive capabilities against experimental data. In the ‘exercise’, selected workers in the area of fibre composite failure theories, including leading academics and developers of software/numerical codes, were invited to submit papers to a strictly controlled format.

The First World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE),1 started in 1996 and came to a fruitful end in 2004 with the publication of a comprehensive reference book on failure criteria in fibre-reinforced polymer composites under two-dimensional (2D) stresses. It contained a detailed assessment of 19 theoretical approaches for predicting the deformation and failure response of polymer composite laminates when subjected to complex states of stress.

A strong feature in the exercise is that it involved those theoreticians and designers who originated the majority of the currently known failure theories. They described their design method in detail, indicated some of the limitations of their methods and specified steps to improve the predictive capability of their theories. The majority of the theory-originators attempted to provide a view and recommendations on how their methodology could be used in design applications. Each participating group was directed to comment only on their own theory thereby fulfilling one of the basic and important objectives of the exercise which was that the originators of the methods are best placed to provide a true and unambiguous interpretation of their own work, thereby eliminating and negating any second guessing by a third party. To this end, their recommendations have been focussed and targeted rendering them very useful indeed to those wishing to adopt one of the methodologies.

The participants employed a wide range of approaches, including micromechanics and finite element based methods, linear and nonlinear analyses, interactive and noninteractive theories, simple and complicated post failure progressive models, etc. The predictions from all the theories were compared with experimental results for 14 test cases, as described in Hinton et al.1 Based on comparing the theoretical predictions of the 19 methods with a large number of test data, reaching 125 observations, it was possible to define the boundaries of predictability of the theories. A scoring system was used to illustrate how far the predictions deviated from the test data for all the 125 observations. Details of the scoring are found in Hinton et al.1

The key findings that emerged from the first WWFE were:
Many of the current predictive theories have insufficient accuracy to be used as design tools and they require fundamental changes if they are ever to reach the requisite maturity.
The better predictive theories exhibited acceptable accuracy in 75% of the test cases, thereby indicating that they could be used as design tools within certain limits.

In addition to the scoring schemes, recommendations were made as to bounds of applicability for each theory (ie those loading/laminate configurations conditions where the theory works well and those where it doesn’t). There was also the occasional lack of crucial experimental data that had some effects on achieving a complete validation and benchmarking of all the theories. These key experiments were identified and listed in Hinton et al.1 and some work has commenced in various establishments to generate the missing data.

In summary, the first WWFE had focussed on the response of classical, continuous fibre, laminated, fibre-reinforced polymer composites subjected to in-plane biaxial loading situations, in the absence of stress concentrations. It proved to be a groundbreaking effort with many achievements:
It established, for the first time, an open and objective way of working in order to compare, contrast and challenge disparate theories from around the world.
It exposed the strengths and weaknesses of the current theories.
As a result of carrying out the first exercise, some 50% of the theories were improved and modified. In some cases, the modifications were made for the first time over 40 years.
It provided a stimulus for researchers to build upon the accurate theoretical features whilst making improvements to deal with the shortfalls that were exposed.
It highlighted gaps in experimental data and in theoretical understanding, and preliminary recommendations were made in terms of prioritisation and approach to their resolution.
It provided design engineers (the ultimate customers for such research knowledge) with recommendations on the preferred theories to use, together with evidence of the level of confidence and bounds of applicability.

Contrasting those achievements is the fact that the exercise did not address the maturity of failure criteria in the following two significant areas:
Area (1): The behaviour of materials under triaxial stresses.
Area (2): Continuum damage mechanics, crack development and initiation of matrix-driven delamination.

As a result, and due to lack of robustness and uncertainty in the maturity of the current predictive models in those two areas, the authors launched two new exercises, referred to as:
The Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II), tackling Area (1) above.
The Third World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-III), addressing Area (2) above.
This article is concerned with the process of conducting WWFE-II. Future publications are planned for describing WWFE-III.

sec.title: The Second World-Wide Failure Exercise
sec.p:
As mentioned above, a high priority gap, identified in the first WWFE, was the need to examine the fidelity of failure theories when applied to components under 3D (i.e. triaxial) states of stress. A thorough understanding of the triaxial failure behaviour of composites is undoubtedly important in many scenarios and applications, including:
Thick and thin composite (e.g. aircraft wing skin, fuselage, lightweight fighting vehicles, rotor blades in wind turbines, helicopters and others),
Structures that are used in high pressure/high hydrostatic pressure situations (eg high performance pressure vessels, deep diving submersibles, sub-sea systems),
Bolted joints,
Indentations of shells and panels,
Impact and dynamic loadings and ballistic penetration,
Composite manufacturing, and thermal stress build-up.
On a wider level, triaxial failure theories are important tools for providing a fundamental understanding of anisotropic metal forming, rock science and powder compaction technology, etc.

A full characterisation of composites requires a thorough understanding of the failure behaviour under a multiplicity of combined stress states. A general loading of a lamina involves the application of six different stress components, namely three direct stresses (σ1, σ2, σ3) and three shear stresses (τ12, τ13, τ23), as shown in Figure 1, where directions 1, 2 and 3 refer to fibre direction, transverse direction and through-thickness direction. In the general case for anisotropic materials (e.g. composites), nine different strengths are normally required to characterise their overall behaviour under uniaxial loading, applied in the material’s principal axes.

Hence, a lamina could be subjected to one the following six general states of stress of increasing complexity:
State (1) Uniaxial stress: A total of nine different uniaxial stresses could be applied. These are +σ1, −σ1, +σ2, −σ2, +σ3, −σ3, τ12, τ13, or τ23.
State (2) Biaxial stress: A total of 33 stress combinations could be applied. These involve any two combinations of the above six, e.g. −σ3, τ12. The six stresses are ∣σ1∣, ∣σ2∣, ∣σ3∣, τ12, τ13, or τ23.
State (3) Three different stresses: A total of 63 stress combinations could be applied. These could be any three sets of stress, e.g. −σ3, τ12, τ13.
State (4) Four different stresses: A total of 66 stress combinations could be applied. These could be any four sets of stresses, e.g. +σ1, −σ2, +σ3, τ12.
State (5) Five different stresses: A total of 36 stress combinations could be applied. These could be any five sets of stress, e.g. +σ1, +σ2, +σ3, τ12, τ13.
State (6) Six different stresses: A total of 9 stress combinations could be applied. These could be any six sets of stress, e.g. −σ1, −σ2, −σ3, τ12, τ13, τ23.
Figure 1.
A schematic of a composite lamina under triaxial state of stress.

In total, 215 different sets of stresses may be applied to a lamina and these sets are distributed among the above six states of stresses as shown in Figure 2. The figure shows that there are 66 different combinations for State (4) and only 8 for State (6). Figure 2.
Number of stress combinations required to characterise a lamina under various number of applied stresses. Figure 3.
Combinations of stress cases attempted in WWFE-I.

Figure 3 shows the number of sets attempted in the first WWFE. One can clearly see that the WWFE-II challenge of characterising the 3D behaviour of a lamina (and that is before we extend to consider laminates) is significantly greater. The challenge is further increased by the relative lack of maturity of formal test methodologies for generating the 3D data – especially the out of plane (through thickness) components. Difficulties are normally encountered in obtaining all the required information from the tests. Consequently, accurate data representing the behaviour of composites under 3D states of stress are relatively scarce. As a direct consequence of the above deficiencies, reliable predictive methods, if any exist at all, have not been subjected to thorough benchmarking and remain largely invalidated.

In order to meet this need, the authors launched WWFE-II, in 2007, building upon and employing the principles established during the first WWFE, with the objective of extending the assessment of predictive failure criteria from 2D to 3D states of stress. In particular, the WWFE-II involves posing a set of challenging test cases to validate and benchmark the triaxial failure theories. The cases would cover the following areas:
Behaviour of an isotropic polymeric resin material, without fibres under triaxial loading.
Triaxial behaviour of a fibre-reinforced polymer Unidirectional (UD) lamina, made of various fibres and resins, including the resin as above.
3D and through-thickness strength and deformation behaviour of multi-directional laminates under various triaxial stresses.

The loadings considered include:
Effect of hydrostatic pressure on the tensile and compressive strength of an isotropic material (polymer).
Effect of hydrostatic pressure on the longitudinal (along the fibres) and transverse (perpendicular) tensile and compressive failure of a UD lamina and multi-directional laminates.
Effects of hydrostatic pressure on shear strength, shear strain and shear stress strain curves.
Effects of in-plane loading on the through- thickness shear.
Behaviour of composite laminates under through-thickness loadings.

sec.title: Description of the test cases
sec.p:
The test cases in WWFE-II have been chosen carefully to stretch each theory to the full, in order to shed light on their strengths and weaknesses. They are focused on a range of classical, continuous fibre, laminated, reinforced polymer composites subjected, in the absence of stress concentrations, to a variety of triaxial loading conditions. The key issues being explored are:
The means by which the theories distinguish (if at all) between the effects of anisotropy and heterogeneity.
The types of failure mechanism employed and the way that each is implemented within any given theory.
The accuracy and bounds of applicability of each theory.

Twelve test cases were identified for the purpose (see Kaddour and Hinton2 for details). They employed five lay-ups: (1) a base resin with isotropic properties, (2) a unidirectional laminate, (3) a cross-ply laminate, (4) an angle-ply laminate and (5) a quasi-isotropic laminate.

Six different fibre/matrix combinations were used and these are: (1) an epoxy, (2) T300/epoxy, (3) E-glass/epoxy, (4) S-glass/epoxy, (5) A-S Carbon/epoxy and (6) IM7/8551 materials. Full details of the test cases are provided in Table 1. Figure 4 shows a schematic of the laminates and the loading conditions for all 12 test cases. Figure 4.
Schematics of the 12 test cases used in WWFE-II. One base resin specimen, six UD laminae and five multi-directional laminates. Table 1.
Details of the test cases used in WWFE-II
Test case Laminate lay-up Material Required predictions
1 Resin MY750 epoxy σ2 versus σ3 (σ1 = σ3) envelope
2 0° T300/PR319 τ12 versus σ2 (σ1 = σ2 = σ3) envelope
3 0° T300/PR319 γ12 versus σ2 (σ1 = σ2 = σ3) envelope
4 0° T300/PR319 Shear stress strain curves (τ12 − γ12) (for σ1 = σ2 = σ3 = −600 MPa)
5 90° E-glass/MY750 σ2 versus σ3 (σ1 = σ3) envelope
6 0° S-glass/epoxy σ1 versus σ3 (σ2 = σ3) envelope
7 0° Carbon/epoxy σ1 versus σ3 (σ2 = σ3) envelope
8 ±35° E-glass/MY750 σy versus σz (σx= σz) envelope
9 ±35° E-glass/MY750 Stress–strain curves (σy − εx and σy − εy) at σz = σx = −100 MPa
10 (0°/90°/±45°)s IM7/8551-7 τyz versus σz (σy = σx = 0) envelope
11 (0°/90°)s IM7/8551-7 τyz versus σz (σy = σx = 0) envelope
12 (0°/90°)s IM7/8551-7 Stress–strain curves (σz − εz, σz − εx and σz − εy) for σy = σx = 0

sec.title: The Participants and their associated theories
Participants
sec.p: A guiding principle employed by the organisers has been to invite the originator of a leading theory to act as the participant in the exercise, rather than utilising third party experts who might stray in their interpretation of the theory from that intended originally. Where direct contributions from the originator has proven to be impractical, connections have been made between the participant and the originator to minimise any variations and/or identify the reasons for such.

The organisers started WWFE-II by approaching those original participants in WWFE who had presented potential 3D theories in the first instance. Table 2 shows the participants of the first WWFE and highlights the names of those who are taking part in WWFE-II. Table 2.
A summary showing the participants who took part in WWFE-I and who agreed to contribute to WWFE-II
Contributor(s) Organisation WWFE-II Participation

Sun CT and Tao JX (see Chap 3.9 and 5.8 in Hinton et al.1) Purdue University School of Aeronautics & Astronautics, West Lafayette, Indiana, USA. No
Chamis CC, Gotsis PK and Minnetyan L (see Chap 31 and 5.1 in Hinton et al.1) NASA Lewis, Cleveland, USA No (1)
McCartney LN (see Chap 3.4 and 5.5 in Hinton et al.1) National Physical Laboratory, UK No (1)
Eckold GC (see Chap 3.2 and 5.2 in Hinton et al.1) AEA Technology, UK No (2)
Edge EC (see Chap 3.3 and 3.3 in Hinton et al.1) British Aerospace, Warton, UK No (3)
Zinoviev P, Grigoriev SV, Labedeva OV and Tairova L (see Chap 3.12 and 5.11 in Hinton et al.1) Institute of Composite Technologies, Orevo, Moskovkaya, Russia. No (3)
Bogetti T, Hoppel C, Harik V, Newill J and Burns B (see Chap 3.13 and 5.12 in Hinton et al.1) ARL, AMSRL-WM-MB, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD 21005, USA Yes
Cuntze R and A Freund (see Chap 3.14 and 5.13 in Hinton et al.1) MAN Technologies, Germany Yes
Rotem A (see Chap 3.8 and 5.7 in Hinton et al.1) Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel Yes
Wolfe WE and Butalia TS (see Chap 3.11 and 5.10 in Hinton et al.1) Department of Civil Engineering, Ohio State University, Ohio. USA Yes
Huang Z-M (see Chap 3.16 and 5.15 in Hinton et al.1) Department of Engineering Mechanics, Tongji University, Shanghai, China Yes
Mayes SJ and Hansen AC (see Chap 31.5 and 5.14 in Hinton et al.1) US Naval Surface Warfare Center, West Bethesda, MD, and Alfred University Yes (4)
Puck A and Schürmann H (see Chap 3.7 and 5.6 in Hinton et al.1) Technische Hochchule, Darmstadt, Germany Yes (4)
Tsai SW and Liu K-S (see Chap 3.10 and 5.9 in Hinton et al.1) Aeronautics and Astronautics Department, Stanford University, California, USA Yes (4)
(1) Participating in the third exercise (WWFE-III).
(2) No response.
(3) Edge, Zinoviev and Mayes are sadly passed away.
(4) With new participants, representing the same method used in WWFE.

The table shows the following:
Eight of the fifteen original participating groups accepted the invitation and have taken part in WWFE-II, thereby providing valuable continuity between the two exercises.
Seven of the original participating groups are not taking part in WWFE-II for the following reasons:
Leaders of two of the groups and the originators of those theories (Zinoviev, Edge) are sadly no longer with us. No suitable substitute was found.
Two groups, (those led by McCartney and Chamis respectively), are taking part in WWFE-III and therefore wished to concentrate their efforts on that.
The situation of the other three groups is as follows:
Sun did not have time, due to heavy commitments and other duties.
Hart-Smith wanted to take part, started working but could not finish.
Eckold did not respond.

With regard to Hart-Smith, his reasoning for not taking part is as follows:
He believes he has a criterion for fibre failure, as described in his contributions to the first exercise.
He does not have a criterion for matrix failure.
Hart-Smith made attempts to team up with one of his colleagues, Gosse,3 to subject a new criterion, known as the strain invariant failure theory (SIFT), to the benchmarking process identified in this exercise. However, he was unable to make successful communications with Gosse, who was the originator of SIFT. As a result, he made other attempts to work with another colleague from the Boeing Company and those attempts came to a halt as Hart-Smith retired from the Boeing Company.

The organisers had also invited other people who were thought to have worked on failure under 3D stresses. The total number of groups invited was around 60, covering academia, experimentalists, software houses, research institutes, and spread through-out the international community. More than a third agreed to take part, some of which then withdrew. Around a third declined to participate, due to a variety of reasons (lack of available resource being a common issue) reasons. Finally, under a third did not respond, partly due to a lack of knowledge of the WWFE activities. The Appendices 1, 2 and 3, at the end of the article, show a list of those who were invited and (a) did not respond, (b) declined and (c) accepted and were provided with datapacks, for Part A and all relevant instructions, and then later withdrew.

A list of contributors currently taking part in WWFE-II is shown in Table 3. The list consists of 12 groups (covering 35 individuals as leaders and co-workers in the field), eight of which took part in the first exercise. The participants represent some twelve institutions /groups /individuals from seven countries. The ‘original’ eight were supplemented by inviting those who were regarded as representative of contemporary modelling tools and methodologies currently in use by research and design institutes around the world. The new four groups are:
Carrere, Laurin and Maire (ONERA, France), representing a new model.
Pinho, Darvizeh, Robinson, Schuecker, Camanho (Imperial College (UK), University of Porto (Portugal)), representing a new model.
Kress (ETZ Zurich, Switzerland), representing Hashin’s theory, and
Ye and Zhang (Leeds University, Manchester University (UK)), representing Christensen’s theory.
Table 3.

Table 3 provides a summary of the participants, their institute, affiliation and references to the theory that each has employed.

sec.title: Methodologies employed in WWFE-II
sec.p: The WWFE-II contains 12 different methods and failure criteria that have been employed, mainly, by their originators.

sec.title: Bogetti’s model
sec.p: This was represented by Bogetti et al.,4 in the same manner was that done in the first exercise. The model employs nonlinear 3D maximum strain failure criterion.

sec.title: Carrere, Laurin and Maire’s model
sec.p: This model is proposed by a group from ONERA (France) who have been working on the development of physically based failure models. The group has worked closely with Chobache (ONERA) on damage modeling and on developing multiscale progressive failure models. They provided a new methodology that was described as micromechanical based hybrid mesoscopic (MHM) 3D approach which was capable of solving all the test cases.5 It takes into account thermal stresses and nonlinearity due to material and progressive failure. The model is able to identify various modes of failure.

sec.title: Cuntze’s model
sec.p: Cuntze, a retired engineer, provided a failure criterion, known as failure mode concept (FMC) model, for predicting failure under 3D stresses.6 The model is an extension to that described in the first WWFE. The new model was employed to solve all the test cases, except test case 10.

sec.title: Ha–Tsai’s model
sec.p: Tsai’s failure criterion was an important part of the first WWFE. He employed the interactive failure method, widely known as Tsai–Wu’s criterion, to solve all the problems of that exercise. Based on the comparison study between the prediction of this criterion and available test data, it was noted that some aspects of the criterion did not capture some of the observations of some of the experimental data. These aspects involve the large enhancement in the biaxial compressive strength of a unidirectional lamina and its knock-on effect on the prediction of the strength of aircraft qualified composite laminates, such as quasi-isotropic carbon/epoxy composites.

Recently, Tsai published a book,7 in which a new failure criterion was provided by Ha.8 The criterion, known as micro-mechanics of failure (MMF), described by Ha, deviated from the original suggested by Tsai in many aspects, including (a) the elimination of the enhancement in the biaxial compressive strength predicted by the original Tsai–Wu’s theory (b) employment of finite element analysis to carry out the micro-mechanical analysis and (c) introduction of physically based criteria for fibre failure, matrix failure and interface failure.
At the end, Tsai together with a group from South Korea, led by Sung Ha, have provided a valuable contribution to WWFE-II. Their model will be referred to in WWFE-II as Ha-Tsai’s model.

sec.title: Hansen et al model
sec.p: Hansen with his group at Wyoming University and FireHole Technology (USA) have provided a contribution based on the multi-continuum theory (MCT), proposed in the first WWFE. Their model was previously referred to as Mayes’s theory. The model uses a finite element analysis to predict failure on a microscopic level (matrix and fibres). They introduced new modifications to the model in order to increase its ability to predict the behaviour under 3D stresses.9

sec.title: Huang’s model
sec.p: This was introduced by Huang in the first exercise. It is a micro-mechanics based analysis and uses bridging approach for predicting elastic constants. It also employs a generalised maximum stress criterion together with a plasticity model to predict the behaviour of the plastic matrix used in the composites.10

sec.title: Hashin’s model
sec.p: Hashin’s theory was developed in the 1980s and had been embedded as a failure criterion in many commercial codes, including ABAQUS, a widely used commercial finite element package.

During the WWFE-II, Hashin was approached by the organisers to take part. He indicated that he was unable to prepare a full paper due to a lack of time and resources, although he was keen on the triaxial test data and suggested to contact one of his colleagues. However, it was not possible to obtain a response from his colleague.

Kress,11 who joined the exercise at relatively late stages, was requested by the organisers to employ Hashin’s theory to solve the test cases. In order to comply with spirit of the exercise and involve Hashin, indirectly, the organisers suggested that Kress and Hashin work together on the paper’s submission.

sec.title: Pinho et al. model
sec.p: Pinho and his group at Imperial College (UK), University of Porto (Portugal) and NASA (USA) has been working on the development of 3D physically based failure methodologies. They provided a new method which was capable of solving all the test cases. The method was used in conjunction with finite element analysis and takes into account pressure dependency, nonlinear material behaviour, damage, fibre buckling and other phenomenological aspects of failure modes.12

sec.title: Puck’s model
sec.p: Puck’s method was one of the models that was benchmarked under 2D stresses in the first WWFE,1 and that was employed by Puck and Schürmann. They used an analytical computer code to solve the test cases.

In the WWFE-II, Schürmann started employing the same analytical code for solving the new test cases. However, another group at ISD (Stuttgart University, Germany), led by Kröplin,13 was working on the use of finite element code for solving and carrying out 3D stress analysis of composite structures. It transpired that Puck had made communications with this group to discuss participating in the WWFE-II. As a result, Schürmann withdrew from the WWFE-II in favour of Kröplin’s group.

At the end, Puck’s method was used by Deuschle and Kröplin,13 with a direct consultation and supervision from Puck, to solve all the 12 test cases. Hence, the model that was presented by Deuschle and Kröplin will be referred to as Puck’s model.

sec.title: Rotem’s model
sec.p: This was represented by Rotem himself. The theory assumes a form of interaction between the various stresses acting on a lamina. In order to cater for 3D stresses, Rotem introduced new terms to the model he used in the first exercise.14

sec.title: Wolfe’s theory
sec.p: This is based on the maximum strain energy principle that was originally carried out by Sandhu. Wolfe and Butalia,1 made a good contribution to the first exercise where they introduced modification to the theories, based upon the available experimental results under 2D stresses. Wolfe and Butalia, together with their colleagues (Zand and Schoeppner15), made other modifications to the theory to cater for 3D stress states. The theory was able to solve all the test cases of the WWFE-II.

sec.title: Christensen’s theory
sec.p: Christensen was approached by the organisers but he indicated that he was unable to prepare a full paper. Ye et al.16 was requested to employ Christensen’s theory to solve the test cases. In order to involve Christensen, indirectly, the organisers suggested that both Ye and Christensen work together to benchmark the original theory. Ye et al.16 attempted to solve the majority of the test cases, except cases 10 and 11 and used linear analysis with no post failure modeling. Their model will be referred to in WWFE-II as Christensen’s model.

sec.title: Methodologies not employed in WWFE-II
sec.p: While the groups participating in the exercise have provided a large spectrum of available models, unfortunately no willing champions/originators would step forward to allow the evaluation of the following theories:

sec.title: Maximum stress model
sec.p: This was presented by Zinoviev in the first exercise.1 This is very simple to use for predicting the behaviour of a lamina under various 3D stresses. However, after the death of Peter Zinoviev our attempts to find an advocate from Peter’s former team to represent his theory in WWFE-II proved to be unsuccessful.

sec.title: Strain invariant failure theory
sec.p: This has been developed by Gosse,3 and it is believed that the development was part of an interaction between Gosse and Hart-Smith, when the latter was at the Boeing company. The organisers have invited both Gosse and Hart-Smith to take part in the exercise to gain greater insight into the theory. A number of contacts and communications were made with Hart-Smith and Gosse. As late as July 2009, and after a meeting between Gosse and the organisers held at ICCM-17 in Edinburgh, the organisers have provided Gosse with a small portion of the WWFE-II test cases to try the method on. The expectation is that a further effort might lead to Gosse attempting the WWFE test cases at a later date.

sec.title: Dissipated energy density theory
sec.p: The dissipated energy density (DED) approach, developed by Badaliance et al.,18 at the Naval Research Laboratory (NRL, USA), is a significant departure from the existing failure methodologies. The organisers invited participation from the team who have pioneered this approach behind the methods and no response was received.

sec.title: Theories based on probabilistic methods
sec.p: Methods for predicting the failure strength of brittle materials (e.g. ceramics) recognise the need to represent material strength as a statistical distribution, rather than as a single valued function. Given that many of the FRP mechanisms could be classed as ‘brittle’ (e.g. transverse tensile fracture of a lamina), one would expect there to be advocates for probabilistic based FRP failure theories. No such advocate emerged from the publicity/selection stage, though it should be noted that one small portion of Cuntze’s contribution does utilise some probabilistic features.

sec.title: Other theories
sec.p:
There are other theories that have not been represented in the exercise and these include those that were presented in the first exercise:1
National and international standards, see Eckold in Hinton et al.1
Ten-percent rule, see Hart-Smith in Hinton et al.1
Generalised Tresca, see Hart-Smith in Hinton et al.1
Chamis’s theory, see Chamis et al. in Hinton et al.1

Hopefully the examples given above serve to show that the organisers have made every possible effort to engage with the broadest base of theoreticians and to encourage their involvement in WWFE-II. Whilst it has not always been possible to get full participation within the framework of WWFE-II itself, the expectation is that some of these groups (or their representatives and collaborators) will choose to attempt the test cases defined in the first WWFE and WWFE-II at a later date, and then produce papers indicating how well their theories have performed. Such new papers are not expected to have the same authority as those generated under the strict rules of the exercise, because the predictions will not be made ‘blind’. Nevertheless they can add to the collective understanding of this very complex area.

sec.title: Review process and timelines and publication
sec.p: All of the participants were sent an identical set of input data which was finalised after receiving feedback from participants (eg requests for additional parameters, clarification of details on loading/laminate configurations etc). Deadlines were set out so that all papers would be submitted on time. The papers were subjected to a stringent reviewing process, where each paper was reviewed at least once (and more typically requiring 3 iterations of revisions). The organisers had to extend the deadlines on a number of occasions to allow those who had not managed to submit their first or revised drafts to complete their work. Although the majority submitted their draft relatively early in the process, a few took a considerable amount of extra time – an inevitable feature of this form of collaborative working and best managed by having regular communication between organisers and participants to encourage progress.

WWFE-II is being run in two parts, following the guidelines adopted in the first WWFE:
Part A is devoted to providing full details of the theoretical models and failure criteria of the participants and the results of their blind predictions.
Part B is concerned with comparing the theoretical results with experimental results.

The WWFE-II is organised to run logically through a series of activities (Table 4). Table 4.
A brief description of the stages used to complete WWFE-II
Activity
1 - Definition of the scope of WWFE-II (Selection of Test Cases and supporting data)
2 - Identifying suitable participants /gaining their agreement to participate
3 - Issuing Part A data to participants
4 - Receipt of Part A submissions
5 - Issuing Part B experimental data to participants
6 - Publication of Part A in special edition of a suitable journal
7 - Receipt of Part B submissions
8 - Publication of Part B in special edition of a suitable journal
9 - Publication of Part A and Part B in a text book
The arrangement allows both a ‘blind test’ and a further opportunity for participants to offer refinements to the theories.

This Part A special issue has dealt with steps 1–4 and 5 in the above table. It contains, in addition to this paper, 14 other papers consisting of:
A paper,2 written by the organisers regarding the input data and instructions and guidelines for Part A.
A series of 12 papers submitted by the participants.4–6,8–16
A paper,17 written by the organisers summarising and comparing the theoretical predictions of all the 12 methods used.
At the time of completing this article, the organisers have issued the Part B experimental data packs to the participants. Readers are urged to watch the space and wait for the completion of Part B!

list-item.p: This paper has set the scene regarding the background objectives and approach taken to deliver WWFE-2 and more specifically, Part A of WWFE-II.
Twelve leading, and internationally recognised, groups have taken part in the WWFE-II by employing their methods to solve 12 challenging test cases.

A future publication will contain the results from Part B of WWFE-II, where the accuracy and maturity of the theories will be assessed by comparing the blind predictions with the experimental evidence.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors would like to thank the participants who took part in this world-wide activity for their dedication and for the immense amount of high quality work that each has contributed. The authors also would like Professor Paul Smith (The University of Surrey, UK) and Dr Shuguang Li (Nottingham University, UK) for their advisory role throughout the work. One of the authors (Dr Kaddour) would like to thank the Royal Society in the UK for granting him the Royal Society Industry Fellowship.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: A part of this work carried out here was sponsored by the Royal Society in the United Kingdom.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
